Below, the missing lightkeeper, Thomas, had vanished completely, leaving only his rain slicker and a cryptic note reading, 'The bell tolls for the wrong ship.' The only witness, a retired sailor named Silas, sat in the base cottage, mending nets and muttering. "He followed the light into the fog, Detective," Silas rasped, his eyes fixed on the sea. "You cannot catch a shadow that has walked off the edge of the world." Anna ignored the sailor’s poetic nonsense, returning her attention to the logbook. The last entry detailed an unusually powerful solar storm two days prior—the day Thomas disappeared. The solar storm hadn't damaged the light, but it had scrambled the radio. Silas then revealed a strange detail: Thomas had been obsessed with a single piece of bronze nautical equipment—a tiny, antique sextant. When Anna found the sextant hidden under the floorboards, it was not pointing toward the sea, but toward the land, specifically, the deepest part of the dense, rocky cliff face. Anna realized the lighthouse wasn't a beacon for incoming ships; it was a directional marker for something coming from the shore. The note wasn't about the *sea* at all. The 'ship' was the name of a local smuggling cartel Thomas had been investigating, and the bell was a warning that the cartel was about to make a massive delivery. Thomas hadn't disappeared into the fog; he had been dragged into the rocky caves beneath the lighthouse, trying to stop the smuggling ring's final run.
